When to use Accusative:: 1. Direct Object of a Verb - It is used to indicate the object that receives the action of the verb.
2. After Certain Prepositions - The accusative case is used after specific prepositions, particularly to indicate motion toward a destination. Such as: na, w, przez, za, pod

Rodzaj Męski:
- Mam dużego kota
- Mam duży dom
- Mam niebieski sweter
Rodzaj Zeński:
- Znam twoją siostrę
- Czytam ciekawą książkę
Rodzaj Niyaki:
- Mam sportowe auto
- Jem dobre śniadanie
- Masz ładne imię
When to use Accusative::
3. When expressing time duration - When we want to say how long something took, then we use the Accusative Case. Eg:
- Stałem w korku dwie godziny. - I was stuck in traffic for two hours.
As a general rule: When using a sentence with a verb, if there is no reason to use a specific case, accusative is probably correct

-y (after sz, ż/rz, cz, dż, c, dz) *

- y
- i (after k or g)

When to use Accusative::
* When using the declensions, the following changes will also happen:
- mobile ‘e’ removed => Budynek becomes Budynku
- mobile ‘ie’ removed => Cukier becomes Cukru
- ó becomes o => Samochód becomes Samochodu
- ą becomes ę => Krąg becomes Kręg

- Mam duże domy
- Mam niebieskie swetry

Rodzaj Niyaki:
- Mam sportowe auta
- Jem dobre śniadania
- Macie dobre imiona

Rodzaj Męski: Co in accusative is used to identify the recepient of the verb action. Similarly, kogo is used to show who is receiving the action

Co widzisz?
What do you see?

I see a cat
